edge: Bond is an MI6 operative.
Bond becomes a 00 agent by earning his 'licence to kill' and assassinating the traitorous Dryden in Prague.
Obanno is a high-ranking member of the Lord's Resistance Army.
Le Chiffre is an Albanian private banker to terrorists.
Obanno entrusts Le Chiffre with $100 million.
Using knowledge of his upcoming terrorist attack on aerospace manufacturer Skyfleet, Le Chiffre shorts the company's stock.
Bond destroys an embassy while capturing and then killing Mollaka, causing an international incident which M criticises Bond for. Mollaka's phone leads Bond to Alex Dimitrios.
Le Chiffre hires Mollaka to bomb Skyfleet's prototype airliner at his request.
Bond wins Dimitrios's vintage Aston Martin in a poker game and seduces his wife Solange. Bond pursues Dimitrios to Miami and fights off an attack by him.
Alex Dimitrios had hired a new bomber at the request of Le Chiffre, to destroy the Skyfleet airliner.
Le Chiffre tortures Solange to death when he realizes that somebody talked about the terrorist plot.

organizes a Texas hold 'em tournament at the Casino Royale in Montenegro to recoup his client's money for MI6 enters Bond, believing a defeat will force Le Chiffre to seek asylum with the British government in exchange for information on his clients.

Brosnan had signed a deal for four films and this was fulfilled with the production of Die Another Day in 2002, officially announcing his stepping down from the role of James Bond in February 2004.
At one point, producer Michael G. Wilson claimed over 200 names were being considered for Craig's replacement after Brosnan stepped down.
Croatian actor Goran Višnjić auditioned for the role of James Bond on the same day as Craig, but was reportedly unable to master an English accent.
Henry Cavill was the only other actor in serious contention for the role after Craig, but at 22 years old, he was considered too young according to Martin Campbell.
According to Martin Campbell, Henry Cavill was the only other actor in serious contention for the role after Craig, but at 22 years old, he was considered too young.

[...] You can see it in their eyes, you know immediately: oh, hello, he's a killer. There's a look. These guys walk into a room and very subtly they check the perimeters for an exit. That's the sort of thing I wanted."

In 2005, Daniel Craig was announced as the sixth actor to play James Bond by Eon Productions, Sony Pictures Entertainment, and MGM. This decision sparked controversy among critics and fans who expressed doubt about the producers' choice. The Daily Mirror even ran a critical headline, 'The Name's Bland - James Bland', due to Craig's perceived lack of tall, dark, handsome, and charismatic qualities associated with the character. However, despite requests to dye his hair brown, Craig refused, instead opting for a shorter, more brutal hairstyle.

In 2005, Eon Productions and Sony Pictures Entertainment jointly announced that Daniel Craig would be the new James Bond. This decision was met with controversy among critics and fans who expressed doubts about the producers' choice.

Throughout the production period of Craig's Bond debut, Internet campaigns such as 'danielcraigisnotbond.com' expressed their dissatisfaction with the new actor and threatened to boycott the film in protest.

The Skyfleet S570 aircraft in the film was an ex-British Airways 747-200B G-BDXJ, which had its engines removed and was modified for its appearance in the film. The modified aircraft had the outboard engines replaced by external fuel tanks, while the inboard engines were replaced by a mock-up pair of engines on each inboard pylon.
The cockpit profile was altered to make the 747 look like a prototype of an advanced airliner.
In filming the scene in which the engine thrust of the moving aircraft blows the police car high into the air, footage from both the Prague and Miami airports were used.
The sequence at Miami International Airport was partly shot at the Dunsfold Aerodrome, in Surrey, which is known from British car show Top Gear,
The engine thrust of the moving aircraft blows the police car high into the air.
The sinking of the Venetian house at the climax of the film featured the largest rig ever built for a Bond film.

node_2: largest rig ever built for a bond film
edge: The largest rig ever built for a Bond film was used in the film.
The computer system closely controlled the electronics with hydraulic valves on the rig.
The same computer system also controlled the exterior model in the film.
At the time of filming, Aston Martin was still in the final phases of designing the DBS.
Aston Martin delivered two working 'hero' cars to the film.
Three former development DB9s had to be prepared and reinforced to withstand impact as look-a-like stunt cars for the scene involving the car crash.
A white prototype DB9 manual was supplied to the film crew so that the stunt drivers had something to practice with.
Owing to the low centre of gravity of the vehicle, an 18-inch (450 mm) ramp had to be implemented on the road tarmac at Millbrook Proving Grounds.
The stunt driver who performed the stunt had to use an air cannon located behind the driver's seat to propel the car into a roll at the precise moment of impact.
At a speed exceeding 70 mph (113 km/h), the car rotated seven times while being filmed.
The car's roll, which was confirmed by the Guinness Book of Records on 5 November 2006 as a new world record.

In 2012, the movie Casino Royale was released for the third time on Blu-ray with DTS audio and deleted scenes. This edition had fewer special features than the previous one from 2008.

In October 2008, a collector's edition of Casino Royale on DVD was released in the UK. This edition contained additional features such as audio commentary, deleted scenes, and featurettes, along with a storyboard-to-film comparison.
In late 2008, a two-disc Blu-ray version of Casino Royale was released, featuring enhanced interactivity through BD-Live and additional supplementary materials.
To achieve a BBFC 12A rating in the UK, Casino Royale was censored by omitting some of Le Chiffre's sadism and James Bond's reactions in the torture scene.

In the US, two fight scenes were censored to achieve a PG-13 rating for Casino Royale: the fight between Bond and the traitorous MI6 agent's contact Fisher, and the fight between Bond and Obanno in the stairway at the Casino Royale.
In Germany, Casino Royale was censored by omitting a shot of Bond's penis being held by a woman during the scene where Vesper Lynd asks him to trust her.
In China, Casino Royale was censored by removing a scene where Bond spits out beer that he mistakenly believed to be urine.

Craig's portrayal of Bond was particularly praised for embodying Ian Fleming's original portrait of the character as ironic, brutal, and cold. This was noted by critics such as Paul Arendt of BBC Films, Kim Newman of Empire, and Todd McCarthy of Variety.
During production, Craig had been subject to debate by the media and the public as he did not appear to fit Ian Fleming's original portrait of the character as tall, dark, and suave.

Roger Moore stated that Daniel Craig's portrayal of James Bond in Casino Royale impressed him greatly and introduced a more gritty, unrefined edge to the character. Moore described Craig's interpretation as like nothing they had seen before, with Jimmy Bond earning his stripes and making mistakes. The script showed Craig's character as vulnerable, troubled, and flawed, which was quite the opposite of Moore's Bond. Moore praised Craig's performance, saying it was very much the Bond Ian Fleming had described in the books - a ruthless killing machine.

Moore mentioned that he thought Sean Connery might have to move over for Daniel Craig after being impressed by Craig's debut performance in Casino Royale. He also stated that his praise was not heaped lightly and that he had to purchase the DVD himself.
John Beifuss of The Commercial Appeal compared James Bond's learning a lesson about ego in Casino Royale to Greg Brady in his 'Johnny Bravo' phase.
Anthony Lane of The New Yorker compared James Bond's wanting to be 007 in Casino Royale to Greg Brady from the TV series 'The Brady Bunch.'
Raymond Benson, the author of nine Bond novels, called Casino Royale 'a perfect Bond film'.
In December 2006, Casino Royale was named the best film of the year by viewers of Film 2006.
Casino Royale features Daniel Craig in the role of James Bond.

American radio personality Michael Medved gave the film three stars out of four, describing it as 'intriguing, audacious and very original ... more believable and less cartoonish, than previous 007 extravaganzas'.
Michael Medved commented that the 'sometimes sluggish pacing will frustrate some Bond fanatics.'
